required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Intrathecal Hydromorphone for Pain Control After Cesarean Section
clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Intrathecal Hydromorphone and Intrathecal Morphine for Postoperative Analgesia After Cesarean Delivery

lead_sponsor.agency: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

clinical_study.source: Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai

brief_summary.textblock:
The use of intrathecal opioids for analgesia in the setting of cesarean section has become standard obstetric anesthesia practice. Currently, two opioids are commonly used. These opioids are fentanyl and morphine (Duramorph). Intrathecal opioids are an excellent source of analgesia and act to reduce the stress response to surgery.
Currently, most obstetric anesthesiologists use intrathecal morphine for analgesia after cesarean delivery. Morphine provides excellent analgesia for cesarean section. However, use of this medication is associated with side effects such as pruritus and nausea and vomiting.
Recently, multiple obstetric anesthesia groups began to use intrathecal hydromorphone for cesarean delivery when morphine was unavailable. As groups began to use hydromorphone, retrospective data became available that demonstrated its safety and efficacy for use during cesarean section.
In order to fully elucidate the analgesic and side effect properties of hydromorphone for cesarean delivery, a prospective randomized, double blind study comparing morphine and hydromorphone is necessary. The investigators need to understand whether hydromorphone is as effective as morphine for analgesia after cesarean section, and whether it is associated with fewer or more side effects. The results of the study will allow providers to make educated decisions to better care for their patient.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.description: Total dose of fentanyl patient controlled analgesia (pca) used in 24 hours post-op.

secondary_outcome.description: When does the patient need to use the PCA for the first time? This will be used to assess when morphine and hydromorphone first begin to provide analgesia.
Assess pain scores on a scale of 1-5, with higher score indicating more pain.
Patient satisfaction score - total scale of 1-5, with higher score indicating more satisfaction

secondary_outcome.measure: Symptom Scale for Two Specific Side Effects of Nausea and Pruritus
secondary_outcome.description: Symptom scale for nausea and pruritus. Full scale from 1-5, with higher score indicating more symptoms.

arm_group.description: 0.25mg ( 250mcg) intrathecal morphine added to 1.5 mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia in primary cesarean sections
50mcg intrathecal hydromorphone added to 1.5 mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia in primary cesarean sections.

intervention.description: 0.25mg intrathecal morphine is the standard opioid medication the investigators use for analgesia for cesarean sections. It is the control arm.
50mcg intrathecal hydromorphone will be added to 1.5mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Elective primary cesarean section
- Females age 18-40
Exclusion Criteria:
- Emergency cesarean section
- Anesthetic other than spinal
- History of chronic pain or pre-op opioid use
- Allergy to morphine or hydromorphone
- BMI>40

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Recruitment began in April 2014 with enrollment from May 2014 to May 2017

group.title: Intrathecal Morphine
group.description: 0.25mg ( 250mcg) intrathecal morphine added to 1.5 mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia in primary cesarean sections Intrathecal morphine: 0.25mg intrathecal morphine is the standard opioid medication the investigators use for analgesia for cesarean sections. It is the control arm.

group.title: Intrathecal Hydromorphone
group.description: 50mcg intrathecal hydromorphone added to 1.5 mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia in primary cesarean sections. Intrathecal hydromorphone: 50mcg intrathecal hydromorphone will be added to 1.5mg 0.75% bupivicaine for single shot spinal anesthesia.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
